content:
lass="word-wrap-span">BOOKS HE lass="word-wrap-span">TRUSTED. lass="word-wrap-span">One was usually in his hand in those first, mostly happy, years as lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabwe’s leader. He would be home at lass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">House by 5.30pm, slamming doors so that his lass="word-wrap-span">beloved lass="word-wrap-span">Sally would know to come rushing. lass="word-wrap-span">They lass="word-wrap-span">crumpled togelass="word-wrap-span">Ther on a low lass="word-wrap-span">armchair, almost on each olass="word-wrap-span">Ther’s laps, she eating lass="word-wrap-span">custard as he sipped tea. lass="word-wrap-span">Then he would lass="word-wrap-span">drape a long arm round her, while using lass="word-wrap-span">The olass="word-wrap-span">Ther to turn lass="word-wrap-span">The pages of a favourite novel, usually British, often a lass="word-wrap-span">Graham lass="word-wrap-span">Greene.

lass="word-wrap-span">Written words he could love. It was real live people who proved difficult. A shy, surly boy, he sought no friends in Kutama, his village. lass="word-wrap-span">Later he admitted it lass="word-wrap-span">frankly: “I lived in my mind a lot. I liked talking to myself, reciting little poems and so on; reading things aloud to myself.” A loner, he hated scrapping with sticks, running, boys’ lass="word-wrap-span">boisterous games, lass="word-wrap-span">communal life. A brother, Donato, thought him “lazy, just reading all the time”. lass="word-wrap-span">Even at lass="word-wrap-span">chores, in the shade of the bush while snaring birds or tramping in the lass="word-wrap-span">dust to lass="word-wrap-span">herd lass="word-wrap-span">cattle, he would read. “He held the lass="word-wrap-span">book in one hand and the whip in the other. It was a strange thing for all of us to see,” recalled Donato.

lass="word-wrap-span">The Irish priest at St lass="word-wrap-span">Francis lass="word-wrap-span">Xavier, lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Catholic mission in Kutama, told young Robert’s molass="word-wrap-span">Ther that he had “unusual lass="word-wrap-span">gravitas” and would “be an important somebody”. He was at mass lass="word-wrap-span">daily, most lass="word-wrap-span">dutifully after his older brolass="word-wrap-span">Ther, Michael, died from poisoned maize. lass="word-wrap-span">Years of study followed as a teacher: first in lass="word-wrap-span">Southern lass="word-wrap-span">Rhodesia, lass="word-wrap-span">Then at lass="word-wrap-span">Fort lass="word-wrap-span">Hare, lass="word-wrap-span">South Africa, lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">crucible lass="word-wrap-span">For so many African nationalist leaders, and last in lass="word-wrap-span">Ghana, where he met lass="word-wrap-span">Sally.

As an African nationalist in lass="word-wrap-span">Rhodesia, ruled by lass="word-wrap-span">Ian lass="word-wrap-span">Smith in the name of white supremacy, jail was lass="word-wrap-span">inevitable. His 11 years behind bars for opposing white-minority rule he recalled as “a lass="word-wrap-span">chunk of life” pointlessly stolen away. lass="word-wrap-span">Again, lass="word-wrap-span">books sustained him. He lass="word-wrap-span">acquired seven degrees. As it did for lass="word-wrap-span">Mandela, lass="word-wrap-span">Nkrumah and lass="word-wrap-span">Kenyatta, prison also earned him political lass="word-wrap-span">credibility. lass="word-wrap-span">Outdoor activity was harder. In lass="word-wrap-span">Mozambique after his release, as his fellow liberation lass="word-wrap-span">fighters strutted in lass="word-wrap-span">fatigues, he sweltered in a suit.

lass="word-wrap-span">Throughout his life, rivals somehow met timely deaths. lass="word-wrap-span">Cars were lass="word-wrap-span">flattened by lorries on remote roads; lass="word-wrap-span">flames lass="word-wrap-span">devoured a farmlass="word-wrap-span">House; opponents learned to fear high open windows. lass="word-wrap-span">Few loved him. lass="word-wrap-span">The British sometimes sneered. At lass="word-wrap-span">Lancaster lass="word-wrap-span">House in London, amid talk of independence and elections, lass="word-wrap-span">The British foreign secretary found him “reptilian”, “not human”. At home, voters thought olass="word-wrap-span">Therwise. He swept to lass="word-wrap-span">glorious, lass="word-wrap-span">genuine victory in lass="word-wrap-span">The first free election in 1980. To lass="word-wrap-span">The shock and relief of lass="word-wrap-span">Smith and lass="word-wrap-span">The white farmers, he let lass="word-wrap-span">Them stay on and keep lass="word-wrap-span">Their land if lass="word-wrap-span">They lass="word-wrap-span">abstained from politics. lass="word-wrap-span">The teacher lass="word-wrap-span">flourished. lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabweans were among lass="word-wrap-span">The best educated people in Africa, and evenings at lass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">House saw lass="word-wrap-span">The prime minister personally tutoring his staff.

He blamed lass="word-wrap-span">Britain for all ills, including his country’s complete economic collapse which he had brought about in lass="word-wrap-span">The first decade of this century. lass="word-wrap-span">Inflation soared to 500 trillion %; a generation of people fled. lass="word-wrap-span">The British, he claimed, had broken lass="word-wrap-span">Their word on paying for land reform. lass="word-wrap-span">Yet he lass="word-wrap-span">hankered for lass="word-wrap-span">England, London shopping, Savile lass="word-wrap-span">Row, lass="word-wrap-span">cricket and high tea with “lass="word-wrap-span">Johnny” lass="word-wrap-span">Major. He was lass="word-wrap-span">fonder still of royalty, telling with a twinkle of lass="word-wrap-span">The queen’s happiness on visits to lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabwe.

lass="word-wrap-span">Rule by the whip

lass="word-wrap-span">For all the lass="word-wrap-span">books, the whip was never far away. In the early 1980s he turned to lass="word-wrap-span">North Korea to train soldiers to lass="word-wrap-span">crush the main minority tribe, the Ndebele. He admitted his security men had committed some “lass="word-wrap-span">excesses” when entire village communities were lass="word-wrap-span">burnt in their lass="word-wrap-span">huts. He denied talk of 20,000 victims and called himself “lass="word-wrap-span">Forgiving”—“otherwise I would have slaughtered lots of people”. lass="word-wrap-span">Yet his fear of prosecution lass="word-wrap-span">For crimes against lass="word-wrap-span">humanity may have encouraged him to cling to office.

His rule grew lass="word-wrap-span">darker, possibly because lass="word-wrap-span">Sally had died and been replaced by lass="word-wrap-span">Grace, an ex-secretary even lass="word-wrap-span">fonder of shopping and more ambitious for political power. His opponents had once been co-opted; now he lass="word-wrap-span">crushed them. At home young thugs, egged on by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Mugabe, punished white farmers by taking their land away. As a farming economy, lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabwe collapsed.

Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Mugabe never saw tragedy in his country’s lass="word-wrap-span">chaos and immiseration, only meddling by outsiders or vicious threats by rivals. lass="word-wrap-span">The army and his lass="word-wrap-span">Central lass="word-wrap-span">Intelligence Organisation ensured his lass="word-wrap-span">grip on power, rigging elections, killing opponents, closing newspapers and scaring away a generation of bright and tolerant lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabweans who could have led Africa. His people succumbed to hunger, lass="word-wrap-span">AIDS, lass="word-wrap-span">cholera and lass="word-wrap-span">despair. lass="word-wrap-span">Each year he held a more lavish public birthlass="word-wrap-span">day party, lass="word-wrap-span">beaming lass="word-wrap-span">childishly as he cut a massive cake.

In lass="word-wrap-span">The end, it was lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">dismissal and flight abroad of his most trusted lieutenant, Emmerson Mnangagwa, that led to his lass="word-wrap-span">downfall in 2017. lass="word-wrap-span">Grace had overplayed her hand in having him sacked, and lass="word-wrap-span">The army rolled into lass="word-wrap-span">Harare. lass="word-wrap-span">The generals lass="word-wrap-span">glibly insisted this was not a coup, preferring to say lass="word-wrap-span">They were dealing with “traitors”. lass="word-wrap-span">They lass="word-wrap-span">duly installed Mr Mnangagwa as president.

lass="word-wrap-span">Asked why people feared him, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Mugabe said he thought it was “perhaps because I’m quiet, and also because I believe in what I say.” His life was mostly lass="word-wrap-span">frugal: rising early to practise yoga; working lass="word-wrap-span">daily at his desk, in his mustard-yellow chair beside a huge map of lass="word-wrap-span">The world; nibbling rice and corn meal by hand, lass="word-wrap-span">The African way. He showed few of lass="word-wrap-span">The vices—women, lass="word-wrap-span">booze, lass="word-wrap-span">feasts—lass="word-wrap-span">associated with lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">caricature of an African lass="word-wrap-span">dictator. lass="word-wrap-span">But he had lass="word-wrap-span">The usual vanity. lass="word-wrap-span">Asked by lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Economist , well into his 80s, when he would retire, he laughed that he would rule until he was “a hundred years old”. lass="word-wrap-span">The tragedy for lass="word-wrap-span">Zimbabwe was how close he got to keeping his word.
